docs.title: Welcome to FRC Robotics, Where YOU Rule!!!!
docs.text: Welcome to the team stinker! This guide is for new members of our FRC robotics club.

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
• The basics of FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC)
  • Safety and tools
  • Programming, electronics, and CAD
  • How to contribute to the team

Stay curious, ask questions, and have fun!

Dont be a stinker!

docs.title: Introduction to XRP Bots
docs.text: XRP Bots are specialized robots designed for the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). In this section, you'll learn how to create and develop your own XRP bot using the latest tools and technology available to our team.

docs.title: Key Components
docs.text:
1. Chassis
  2. The base structure of your robot.

  3. It can be made from materials like aluminum or steel.

  4. Drive Train

  5. This is the mechanism that allows your robot to move.

  6. Common types: tank drive, mecanum, and swerve.

  7. Programming

  8. Learn how to code your robot to make it do what you want.

  9. We use Java or LabVIEW for programming FRC robots.

  10. Electronics

  11. Wiring and connecting all the components to the robot's control system.

  12. Sensors and Actuators

  13. Use sensors like encoders, cameras, and gyros to gather data and control the robot.
  14. Actuators control movement, like motors and servos.

docs.title: 1. Designing the Chassis
docs.text: Start by sketching your robot's layout and defining the shape of your chassis. Ensure it meets the competition's size requirements.

docs.title: 2. Assembling the Drive Train
docs.text: Choose between different drive systems. For example, if you're building a tank drive, you’ll need two motors for the left and right sides. Ensure that you select the correct motor controllers and wiring.

docs.title: 3. Programming Your XRP Bot
docs.text: Programming the robot requires writing code to control movement, sensors, and actuators. Start by configuring the robot's inputs and outputs.

docs.title: Programming Your XRP Bot
docs.text: Programming the robot requires writing code to control movement, sensors, and actuators. Start by configuring the robot's inputs and outputs.

docs.title: Example Code (in Java):
docs.text:
public class Robot extends TimedRobot {
    private Spark leftMotor = new Spark(0);
    private Spark rightMotor = new Spark(1);

    @Override
    public void teleopPeriodic() {
        double moveSpeed = joystick.getY();
        double turnSpeed = joystick.getX();
        leftMotor.set(moveSpeed + turnSpeed);
        rightMotor.set(moveSpeed - turnSpeed);
    }
}

Go Back to Launch Page
